Quit smoking medication can help you quit. 
•They reduce feelings of withdrawal, reduce your urge to smoke, and improve chances of quitting. They are not a magic bullet, but they come pretty close! 
•Before choosing anyquit smoking medication, talk to your doctor about which medication may be right for you and what, if any, side effects may occur. 
•The products described below have all been approved by Health Canada to assist in quitting. 

Nicotine Replacement Therapy (NRT) 
• The most common forms of NRT are the patch, gum, lozenge, and inhaler. 
• You can buy NRT without a prescription at a drugstore. 
• It gives you some nicotine without the harmful chemicals in cigarette smoke. 
• It fights symptoms like anger, anxiety, cravings, problems concentrating, and restlessness. 
• It works best in combination with other forms of help(e.g. self-help or counseling). 
• Before using NRT tell your doctor or pharmacist about your health conditions, other medications you are taking, and how much you smoke. They will help you choose the right brand and dose and explain how to use the product. They will ask you if you are pregnant or breast feeding. 

Nicotine patches 
 are the easiest NRT products to use and can help heavy smokers who need a constant supply of nicotine. Small amounts of nicotine are continuously absorbed through the skin. 

Nicotine gum 
can help occasional smokers deal with strong cravings as needed through the day. Nicotine enters your system more rapidly than with the patch. You don't chew it like regular gum; you bite and park the gum against your cheek. It is important to choose the right dose based on how many cigarettes per day you smoke. 

Nicotine lozenges 
 are like hard candy, and release nicotine as they dissolve in your mouth. Like the gum, lozenges deliver nicotine to the brain more rapidly than the patch and don't provide a steady dose of nicotine. Lozenges should not be bitten, chewed or swallowed. 
Nicotine inhalers are the fastest method of receiving nicotine and using one mimics the hand to mouth ritual of smoking.
